titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Edith M. Crouse autograph book 1978.035
titlestmt.author: Matthew Gorham
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was originally processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2023-12-27 15:14:48 +0000.
profiledesc.langusage: Description is written in: English, Latin script.

did.abstract: The autograph book of Brooklyn resident Edith M. Crouse, with entries dated 1887-1893, many of which seem to relate to Crouse's 1888 graduation from P.S. 9.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Source and date of acquisition unknown. The item was formally accessioned in 1978.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection consists of a single volume.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Edith M. Crouse lived at 214 Lincoln Place in Brooklyn. She graduated from Brooklyn's School No. 9 in 1888.

list.head: Source:
list.item: "Grammar School Graduates," Brooklyn Times Union, February 25, 1888, p. 2.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: Brooklyn's School No. 9 was built 1867â€“68 and designed by Samuel B. Leonard in the Early Romanesque Revival style. Its two wings were added in 1887 and were designed by James W. Naughton. The school was originally Public School (P.S.) 9, later becoming Public School 111, and is currently M.S. 340, North Star Academy. The building was designated a New York City landmark in 1978 and listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1981.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Edith M. Crouse autograph book, 1887-1893, 1978.035, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was rehoused and the finding aid revised by Dee Bowers in 2023.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The autograph book of Brooklyn resident Edith M. Crouse. The entries in the book appear to have been written by friends and classmates, and many are signed "Class of 1888." According to the Brooklyn Times Union, Crouse was among the graduates of "School No. 9," later P.S. 9.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This item is in the public domain. While many items at the Center for Brooklyn History are unrestricted, we do not own reproduction rights to all materials. Be aware of the several kinds of rights that might apply: copyright, licensing and trademarks. The researcher assumes all responsibility for copyright questions.
